statements.name: PROC UNIVARIATE
statements.description: The UNIVARIATE procedure provides the following: † o descriptive statistics based on moments (including skewness and kurtosis), quantiles or percentiles (such as the median), frequency tables, and extreme values o histograms that optionally can be fitted with probability density curves for various distributions and with kernel density estimates o cumulative distribution function plots (cdf plots). Optionally, these can be superimposed with probability distribution curves for various distributions. o quantile-quantile plots (Q-Q plots), probability plots, and probability-probability plots (P-P plots). These plots facilitate the comparison of a data distribution with various theoretical distributions. o goodness-of-fit tests for a variety of distributions including the normal o the ability to inset summary statistics on plots o the ability to analyze data sets with a frequency variable o the ability to create output data sets containing summary statistics, histogram intervals, and parameters of fitted curves

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all statistics and tables that the FREQ, MODES, NEXTRVAL=5, PLOT, and CIBASIC options generate.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of significance a for 100(1 - α)% confidence intervals.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains annotate variables.

arguments.name: CIBASIC=
arguments.description: Requests confidence limits for the mean, standard deviation, and variance based on the assumption that the data are normally distributed.

arguments.name: CIPCTLDF=
arguments.description: Requests confidence limits for quantiles based on a method that is distribution-free.
arguments.help: CIPCTLDF=TYPE= | ALPHA= | LOWER | UPPER | SYMMETRIC | ASYMMETRIC

arguments.name: CIPCTLNORMAL=
arguments.description: Requests confidence limits for quantiles based on the assumption that the data are normally distributed.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set to be analyzed.

arguments.name: EXCLNPWGT
arguments.description: Excludes observations with nonpositive weight values (zero or negative) from the analysis. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE counts observations with negative or zero weights in the total number of observations. This option applies only when you use a WEIGHT statement.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Requests a frequency table that consists of the variable values, frequencies, cell percentages, and cumulative percentages.

arguments.name: GOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS catalog that PROC UNIVARIATE uses to save traditional graphics output.

arguments.name: IDOUT
arguments.description: Includes ID variables in the output data set created by an OUTPUT statement.

arguments.name: LOCCOUNT
arguments.description: Requests a table that shows the number of observations greater than, not equal to, and less than the value of MU0=. PROC UNIVARIATE uses these values to construct the sign test and the signed rank test. This option does not apply if you use a WEIGHT statement.

arguments.name: MODES
arguments.description: Requests a table of all possible modes.

arguments.name: MU0=
arguments.description: Specifies the value of the mean or location parameter (muo) in the null hypothesis for tests of location summarized in the table labeled "Tests for Location: Mu0=value."

arguments.name: NEXTROBS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of extreme observations that PROC UNIVARIATE lists in the table of extreme observations.

arguments.name: NEXTRVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of extreme values that PROC UNIVARIATE lists in the table of extreme values.

arguments.name: NOBYPLOT
arguments.description: Suppresses side-by-side line printer box plots that are created by default when you use the BY statement and either the ALL option or the PLOT option in the PROC statement.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all the tables of descriptive statistics that the PROC UNIVARIATE statement creates. NOPRINT does not suppress the tables that the HISTOGRAM statement creates.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Requests tests for normality that include a series of goodness-of-fit tests based on the empirical distribution function.

arguments.name: NOTABCONTENTS
arguments.description: Suppresses the table of contents entries for tables of summary statistics produced by the PROC UNIVARIATE statement.

arguments.name: NOVARCONTENTS
arguments.description: Suppresses grouping entries associated with analysis variables in the table of contents. By default, the table of contents lists results associated with an analysis variable in a group with the variable name.

arguments.name: OUTTABLE=
arguments.description: Creates an output data set that contains univariate statistics arranged in tabular form, with one observation per analysis variable.

arguments.name: PCTLDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the definition that PROC UNIVARIATE uses to calculate quantiles.
Definition 1 for computing quantile statistics
Definition 2 for computing quantile statistics
Definition 3 for computing quantile statistics
Definition 4 for computing quantile statistics
Definition 5 for computing quantile statistics

arguments.name: PLOTSIZE
arguments.description: Specifies the approximate number of rows used in line-printer plots requested with the PLOTS option.

arguments.name: PLOTS
arguments.description: Produces a stem-and-leaf plot (or a horizontal bar chart), a box plot, and a normal quantile plot in line printer output.

arguments.name: ROBUSTSCALE
arguments.description: Produces a table with robust estimates of scale.

arguments.name: ROUND=
arguments.description: Specifies the units to use to round the analysis variables prior to computing statistics.

arguments.name: SUMMARYCONTENTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the table of contents entry used for grouping the summary statistics produced by the PROC UNIVARIATE statement.

arguments.name: TRIMMED=
arguments.description: Requests a table of trimmed means, where value specifies the number or the proportion of observations that PROC UNIVARIATE trims.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the divisor to use in the calculation of variances and standard deviation.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus one

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

arguments.name: WINSORIZED=
arguments.description: Requests of a table of Winsorized means, where value is the number or the proportion of observations that PROC UNIVARIATE uses to compute the Winsorized mean.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses for each BY group.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CDFPLOT
statements.description: Plots the observed cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a variable.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the shape parameter α for distribution functions requested with the BETA and GAMMA options.

arguments.name: ALPHADELTA=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in successive estimates of α-hat at which iteration terminates in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option.

arguments.name: ALPHAINITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial value for α-hat in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option. Enclose the ALPHAINITIAL= option in parentheses after the GAMMA keyword.

arguments.name: ANNOKEY
arguments.description: Applies the annotation requested with the ANNOTATE= option only to the key cell of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains annotate variables.

arguments.name: BETA
arguments.description: Displays a fitted beta distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of beta-options:
arguments.help: BETA(ALPHA= | BETA= | SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | L= | W=)

arguments.name: BETA=
arguments.description: Specifies the second shape parameter, β, for beta distribution functions requested by the BETA option.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: Specifies the shape parameter, c, for Weibull distribution functions requested with the WEIBULL option.

arguments.name: CAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the axes and tick marks.

arguments.name: CDELTA=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in successive estimates of c at which iterations terminate in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of c for Weibull distributions requested by the WEIBULL option. Enclose the CDELTA= option in parentheses after the WEIBULL keyword. Iteration continues until the change in between consecutive steps is less than the value specified or until the number of iterations exceeds the value of the MAXITER= option. The default value is 0.00001.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the area that is enclosed by the axes and frame. The area is not filled by default.

arguments.name: CFRAMESIDE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to fill the frame area for the row labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: CFRAMETOP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to fill the frame area for the column labels that display across the top of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: CHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for horizontal axis reference lines requested by the HREF= option.

arguments.name: CINITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial value for c-hat in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of c for Weibull distributions requested with the WEIBULL or WEIBULL2 option. The default value is 1.8.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the COLOR= option in parentheses after a distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of colors in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the table of contents grouping entry for output produced by the plot statement. You can specify CONTENTS='' to suppress the grouping entry.

arguments.name: CPROP
arguments.description: Produces proportion bars that use an appropriate color from the ODS style.

arguments.name: CPROP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for a horizontal bar whose length (relative to the width of the tile) indicates the proportion of the total frequency that is represented by the corresponding cell in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Specifies the color for a horizontal bar whose length (relative to the width of the tile) indicates the proportion of the total frequency that is represented by the corresponding cell in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: EMPTY
arguments.description: Displays empty bars.

arguments.name: CSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the colors for reference lines that you request in the STATREF= option. If you specify a single color, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if fewer colors are specified than reference lines are requested, the remaining lines are displayed with the default reference line color. You can also specify the value _default in the color list to request the default color.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for tick mark values and axis labels. The default is the color specified for the CTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: CTEXTSIDE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the row labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot. By default, the color specified by the CTEXT= option is used. If you omit the CTEXT= option, the color specified in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: CTEXTTOP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the column labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot. By default, the color specified by the CTEXT= option is used. If you omit the CTEXT= option, the color specified in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: CVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for lines requested with the VREF= option.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies a description, up to 256 characters long, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu for a traditional graphics chart. The default value is the analysis variable name.

arguments.name: EXPONENTIAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted exponential distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of exponential-options:

arguments.name: FITINTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the value of z for the method of percentiles when this method is used to fit a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITINTERVAL= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. The default of z is 0.524.

arguments.name: FITMETHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method used to estimate the parameters of a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITMETHOD= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. By default, the method of percentiles is used.

arguments.name: PERCENTILE
arguments.description: Method of percentiles.

arguments.name: MLE
arguments.description: Method of MLE.

arguments.name: MOMENTS
arguments.description: Method of moments.

arguments.name: FITTOLERANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance value for the ratio criterion when the method of percentiles is used to fit a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITTOLERANCE= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. The default value is 0.01.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a software font for reference line and axis labels. You can also specify fonts for axis labels in an AXIS statement. The FONT= font takes precedence over the FTEXT= font specified in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Displays a fitted gamma distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of gamma-options:
arguments.help: GAMMA<(ALPHADELTA= | ALPHAINITIAL= | MAXITER= | SIGMA= | ALPHA= | THETA= | COLOR= | L= | W=)>

arguments.name: GUMBEL
arguments.description: Displays fitted Gumbel density curves on the histogram. You can specify the GUMBEL option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of Gumbel curves. Use the MU= and the SIGMA= Gumbel-options to specify the location parameter μ and the scale parameter σ, respectively. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for μ and σ.

arguments.name: HAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of an AXIS statement describing the horizontal axis.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height, in percentage screen units, of text for axis labels, tick mark labels, and legends. This option takes precedence over the HTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: HMINOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the horizontal axis. Minor tick marks are not labeled. By default, HMINOR=0.

arguments.name: HREF=
arguments.description: Draws reference lines that are perpendicular to the horizontal axis at the values that you specify.

arguments.name: HREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the HREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can have up to 16 characters.

arguments.name: HREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical position of the HREFLABELS= labels.
Along top of plot
Staggered from top to bottom of plot
Along bottom of plot
Staggered from bottom to top of plot

arguments.name: IGAUSS
arguments.description: displays fitted inverse Gaussian density curves on the histogram. You can specify the IGAUSS option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of inverse Gaussian curves. Use the MU= and the LAMBDA= iGauss-options to specify the location parameter μ and the shape parameter λ, respectively. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE uses the sample mean for μ and computes a maximum likelihood estimate for λ.

arguments.name: INFONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a software font to use for text inside the framed areas of the plot. The INFONT= option takes precedence over the FTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: INHEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height, in percentage screen units, of text used inside the framed areas of the histogram. By default, the height specified by the HEIGHT= option is used. If you do not specify the HEIGHT= option, the height specified with the HTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: INTERTILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the distance in horizontal percentage screen units between the framed areas, called tiles, of a comparative plot. By default, INTERTILE=0.75 percentage screen units. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. You can specify INTERTILE=0 to create contiguous tiles.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Requests a table that shows the iteration history and optimizer details of the maximum likelihood parameter estimation of a Weibull distribution that is requested by the WEIBULL or WEIBULL2 option.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: specifies the shape parameter λ for fitted curves that are requested by the IGAUSS option. Enclose the LAMBDA= option in parentheses after the IGAUSS distribution keyword. If you do not specify a value for λ, the procedure calculates a maximum likelihood estimate.

arguments.name: L=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the L= option in parentheses after the distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of line types in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: LHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for the reference lines that you request with the HREF= option. By default, LHREF=2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: LOGNORMAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted lognormal distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of lognormal-options:
arguments.help: LOGNORMAL<(ZETA= | SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | L= | W=)>

arguments.name: LSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line types for the reference lines that you request in the STATREF= option. If you specify a single line type, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if fewer line types are specified than reference lines are requested, the remaining lines are displayed with the default reference line type.

arguments.name: LVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for lines requested with the VREF= option. By default, LVREF=2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option and c for Weibull distributions requested with the WEIBULL and WEIBULL2 options. Enclose the MAXITER= option in parentheses after the GAMMA, WEIBULL, or WEIBULL2 keywords. The default value of n is 20.

arguments.name: MU=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameter, μ, for normal distribution functions requested with the NORMAL option.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a name for the plot, up to eight characters long, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu for a traditional graphics chart. The default value is 'UNIVAR'.

arguments.name: NCOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns per panel in a comparative plot. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. By default, NCOLS=1 if you specify only one CLASS variable, and NCOLS=2 if you specify two CLASS variables. If you specify two CLASS variables, you can use the NCOLS= option with the NROWS= option.

arguments.name: NOCDFLEGEND
arguments.description: suppresses the legend for the superimposed theoretical cumulative distribution function. The NOCDFLEGEND option applies only to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: NOECDF
arguments.description: Suppresses the observed distribution function (the empirical cumulative distribution function) of the variable, which is drawn by default.

arguments.name: NOFRAME
arguments.description: Suppresses the frame around the subplot area.

arguments.name: NOHLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses the label for the horizontal axis. You can use this option to reduce clutter.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted normal distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of normal-options:

arguments.name: NOVLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses the label for the vertical axis. You can use this option to reduce clutter.

arguments.name: NOVTICK
arguments.description: Suppresses the tick marks and tick mark labels for the vertical axis. This option also suppresses the label for the vertical axis.

arguments.name: NROWS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows per panel in a comparative plot. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. By default, NROWS=2. If you specify two CLASS variables, you can use the NCOLS= option with the NROWS= option.

arguments.name: ODSFOOTNOTE=
arguments.description: Adds a footnote to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE statement as the graph footnote.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE1
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE statement as the graph footnote.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the graph footnote. The string can contain either of the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSFOOTNOTE2=
arguments.description: Adds a secondary footnote to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE2
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE2 statement as the secondary graph footnote.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the secondary graph footnote. The string can contain either of the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSTITLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a title for ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: TITLE
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE statement as the graph title.

arguments.name: TITLE1
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE statement as the graph title.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all titles from the graph.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: Uses the default ODS Graphics title (a descriptive title that consists of the plot type and the analysis variable name).

arguments.name: LABELFMT
arguments.description: Uses the default ODS Graphics title with the variable label instead of the variable name.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the graph title. The string can contain the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSTITLE2=
arguments.description: Specifies a secondary title for ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: TITLE2
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE2 statement as the secondary graph title..

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the secondary graph title. The string can contain the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: OVERLAY
arguments.description: Specifies that plots associated with different levels of a CLASS variable be overlaid onto a single plot, rather than displayed as separate cells in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: PARETO
arguments.description: Displays fitted generalized Pareto density curves on the histogram. You can specify the this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of generalized Pareto curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= Pareto-option to specify Θ. By default, THETA=0. Use the SIGMA= and the ALPHA= Pareto-options to specify the scale parameter sigma and the shape parameter a. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for σ and a.

arguments.name: POWER
arguments.description: Displays fitted power function density curves on the histogram. You can specify this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of power function curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= and SIGMA= power-options to specify Θ and σ. The default values are 0 and 1, respectively. Use the ALPHA= power-option to specify the and the shape parameter, a. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes a maximum likelihood estimate for a.

arguments.name: RAYLEIGH
arguments.description: Displays fitted Rayleigh density curves on the histogram. You can specify this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of Rayleigh curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= Rayleigh-option to specify Θ. By default, THETA=0. Use the SIGMA= Rayleigh-option to specify the scale parameter σ. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for σ.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Is an alias for the SIGMA= option for distributions requested by the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, SB, SU, WEIBULL, and WEIBULL2 options and for the ZETA= option for distributions requested by the LOGNORMAL option.

arguments.name: SHAPE=
arguments.description: Is an alias for the ALPHA= option for distributions requested by the GAMMA option, for the SIGMA= option for distributions requested by the LOGNORMAL option, and for the C= option for distributions requested by the WEIBULL and WEIBULL2 options.

arguments.name: SIGMA=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameter, σ, for distribution functions requested by the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, NORMAL, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: STATREF=
arguments.description: draws reference lines at the values of the statistics that are requested in the space-delimited keyword-list. Keywords can be MAX, MEAN, MEDIAN, Q2, MIN, MODE, P p, Q1, Q3, factor STD. These reference lines are perpendicular to the horizontal axis in a histogram or CDF plot, and perpendicular to the vertical axis in a probability or Q-Q plot (unless the ROTATE option is specified). The STATREF= option does not apply to the PPPLOT statement.

arguments.name: STATREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines that you request in the STATREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can be up to 16 characters long.

arguments.name: STATREFSUBCHAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a substitution character (such as #) for labels that you specify in the STATREFLABELS= option. When the labels are displayed in a graph, the first occurrence of the specified character in each label is replaced with the value of the corresponding STATREF= statistic.

arguments.name: THETA=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower threshold parameter, θ, for theoretical cumulative distribution functions requested with the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: THRESHOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower threshold parameter, θ, for theoretical cumulative distribution functions requested with the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: TURNVLABELS
arguments.description: Turns the characters in the vertical axis labels so that they display vertically. This happens by default when you use a hardware font.

arguments.name: VAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of an AXIS statement describing the vertical axis. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can alternatively specify a value-list for the vertical axis.

arguments.name: VAXISLABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a label for the vertical axis. Labels can have up to 40 characters.

arguments.name: VMINOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the vertical axis. Minor tick marks are not labeled. The default is zero.

arguments.name: VREF=
arguments.description: Draws reference lines perpendicular to the vertical axis at the values specified. Also see the CVREF= and LVREF= options.

arguments.name: VREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the VREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can have up to 16 characters.

arguments.name: VREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the horizontal position of the VREFLABELS= labels.
Labels are positioned at the left of the plot.
Labels are positioned at the right of the plot.

arguments.name: VSCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies the scale of the vertical axis.

arguments.name: COUNT
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of the number of observations per data unit.

arguments.name: PERCENT
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of percent of observations per data unit. This is the default.

arguments.name: PROPORTION
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of proportion of observations per data unit.

arguments.name: W=
arguments.description: Specifies the width in pixels of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the W= option in parentheses after the distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of widths in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: WAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, for the axes and frame.

arguments.name: WEIBULL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted Weibull distribution function on the cdf plot. Description of Weibull-options:
arguments.help: WEIBULL          (C= | CDELTA= | CINITIAL= | MAXITER= | SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | L= | W=)

arguments.name: WHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the HREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all HREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: WSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the STATREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: WVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the VREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all VREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: ZETA=
arguments.description: Specifies a value for the scale parameter, ζ, for a lognormal distribution function requested with the LOGNORMAL option.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement specifies one or two variables used to group the data into classification levels.

arguments.name: KEYLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the key cells in comparative plots.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Specifies that missing values for the CLASS variable are to be treated as valid classification levels.

arguments.name: NOKEYMOVE
arguments.description: Specifies that the location of the key cell in a comparative plot be unchanged by the CLASS statement KEYLEVEL= option.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the display order for the CLASS variable values.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. If you use the FREQ statement, the procedure assumes that each observation represents n observations, where n is the value of variable. If the variable is not an integer, the SAS System truncates it. If the variable is less than 1 or is missing, the procedure excludes that observation from the analysis. Note: The FREQ statement affects the degrees of freedom, but the WEIGHT statement does not.

statements.name: HISTOGRAM
statements.description: The HISTOGRAM statement creates histograms and optionally superimposes estimated parametric and nonparametric probability density curves.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the shape parameter α for distribution functions requested with the BETA and GAMMA options.

arguments.name: ALPHADELTA=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in successive estimates of α-hat at which iteration terminates in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option.

arguments.name: ALPHAINITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial value for α-hat in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option. Enclose the ALPHAINITIAL= option in parentheses after the GAMMA keyword.

arguments.name: ANNOKEY
arguments.description: Applies the annotation requested with the ANNOTATE= option only to the key cell of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains annotate variables.

arguments.name: BARFILL=
arguments.description: specifies variables whose values determine the colors of the bars in the cells of a comparative histogram. Cells that are associated with a particular value of a BARFILL= variable are the same color. The colors that are used are determined by the ODS style. If the HISTOGRAM statement applies to more than one analysis variable (which are listed in either the HISTOGRAM statement or a VAR statement), you can specify a list of BARFILL= variables, which are matched with analysis variables by their positions in the lists.

arguments.name: BARLABEL=
arguments.description: Displays labels above the histogram bars.

arguments.name: COUNT
arguments.description: The label shows the number of observations associated with a given bar.

arguments.name: PERCENT
arguments.description: The label shows the percentage of observations represented by that bar.

arguments.name: PROPORTION
arguments.description: The label displays the proportion of observations associated with the bar.

arguments.name: BARWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of the histogram bars in percentage screen units.)>

arguments.name: BETA
arguments.description: Displays a fitted beta distribution function on the histogram. You can specify the following beta-options:
arguments.help: BETA(ALPHA= | BETA= | SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | L= | W= | CONTENTS= | FILL | MIDDLEPERCENTS | NOPRINT | PERCENTS= | W=)

arguments.name: BETA=
arguments.description: Specifies the second shape parameter, β, for beta density curves requested by the BETA option.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: Specifies the shape parameter, c, for Weibull distribution functions requested with the WEIBULL option.

arguments.name: CAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the axes and tick marks.

arguments.name: CBARLINE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the outline of the histogram bars when producing traditional graphics.

arguments.name: CDELTA=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in successive estimates of c at which iterations terminate in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of c for Weibull distributions requested by the WEIBULL option. Enclose the CDELTA= option in parentheses after the WEIBULL keyword. Iteration continues until the change in between consecutive steps is less than the value specified or until the number of iterations exceeds the value of the MAXITER= option. The default value is 0.00001.

arguments.name: CFILL=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to fill the bars of the histogram (or the area under a fitted density curve if you also specify the FILL option) when producing traditional graphics.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the area that is enclosed by the axes and frame. The area is not filled by default.

arguments.name: CFRAMESIDE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to fill the frame area for the row labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: CFRAMETOP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to fill the frame area for the column labels that display across the top of a comparative plot.

arguments.name: CGRID=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for grid lines when a grid displays on the histogram in traditional graphics.

arguments.name: CHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for horizontal axis reference lines requested by the HREF= option.

arguments.name: CINITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial value for c-hat in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of c for Weibull distributions requested with the WEIBULL or WEIBULL2 option. The default value is 1.8.

arguments.name: CLIPCURVES
arguments.description: Scales the vertical axis without taking fitted curves into consideration. Curves that extend above the tallest histogram bar can be clipped. You can use this option to avoid compression of the histogram bars that can be caused by extremely high fitted curve peaks.

arguments.name: CLIPREF
arguments.description: Draws reference lines requested with the HREF= and VREF= options behind the histogram bars.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the COLOR= option in parentheses after a distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of colors in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the table of contents grouping entry for output produced by the plot statement. You can specify CONTENTS='' to suppress the grouping entry.

arguments.name: CPROP
arguments.description: Produces proportion bars that use an appropriate color from the ODS style.

arguments.name: CPROP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for a horizontal bar whose length (relative to the width of the tile) indicates the proportion of the total frequency that is represented by the corresponding cell in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Specifies the color for a horizontal bar whose length (relative to the width of the tile) indicates the proportion of the total frequency that is represented by the corresponding cell in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: CSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the colors for reference lines that you request in the STATREF= option. If you specify a single color, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if fewer colors are specified than reference lines are requested, the remaining lines are displayed with the default reference line color. You can also specify the value _default in the color list to request the default color.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for tick mark values and axis labels. The default is the color specified for the CTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: CTEXTSIDE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the row labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot. By default, the color specified by the CTEXT= option is used. If you omit the CTEXT= option, the color specified in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: CTEXTTOP=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the column labels that display along the left side of a comparative plot. By default, the color specified by the CTEXT= option is used. If you omit the CTEXT= option, the color specified in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: CVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for lines requested with the VREF= option.

arguments.name: DELTA=
arguments.description: Specifies the first shape parameter, d, for Johnson sB and Johnson sU distribution functions requested with the SB and SU options.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies a description, up to 256 characters long, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu for a traditional graphics chart. The default value is the analysis variable name.

arguments.name: EDFNSAMPLES=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of simulation samples to use to compute p-values for empirical distribution function (EDF) goodness-of-fit statistics for density curves that are requested by the GUMBEL, IGAUSS, PARETO, and RAYLEIGH options. Enclose the EDFNSAMPLES= option in parentheses after the distribution option. By default, EDFNSAMPLES=500.

arguments.name: EDFSEED=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer value to use to start the pseudorandom number generator when creating simulation samples for computing EDF goodness-of-fit statistic p-values for density curves that are requested by the GUMBEL, IGAUSS, PARETO, and RAYLEIGH options. Enclose the EDFSEED= option in parentheses after the distribution option. By default, the procedure uses a random number seed that is generated from reading the time of day from the computer’s clock.

arguments.name: ENDPOINTS
arguments.description: Uses histogram bin endpoints as the tick mark values for the horizontal axis and determines how to compute the bin width of the histogram bars.

arguments.name: EXPONENTIAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted exponential distribution function on the histogram. You can specify the following exponential-options:
arguments.help: EXPONENTIAL<(SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | CONTENTS= | FILL | L= | W= | MIDPERCENTS | NOPRINT | PERCENTS=)>

arguments.name: FILL
arguments.description: Fills areas under the fitted density curve or the kernel density estimate with colors and patterns.

arguments.name: FITINTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the value of z for the method of percentiles when this method is used to fit a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITINTERVAL= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. The default of z is 0.524.

arguments.name: FITMETHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method used to estimate the parameters of a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITMETHOD= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. By default, the method of percentiles is used.

arguments.name: PERCENTILE
arguments.description: Method of percentiles.

arguments.name: MLE
arguments.description: Method of MLE.

arguments.name: MOMENTS
arguments.description: Method of moments.

arguments.name: FITTOLERANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance value for the ratio criterion when the method of percentiles is used to fit a Johnson sB or Johnson sU distribution. The FITTOLERANCE= option is specified in parentheses after the SB or SU option. The default value is 0.01.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a software font for reference line and axis labels. You can also specify fonts for axis labels in an AXIS statement. The FONT= font takes precedence over the FTEXT= font specified in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: FORCEHIST
arguments.description: Forces the creation of a histogram if there is only one unique observation.

arguments.name: FRONTREF
arguments.description: Draws reference lines requested with the HREF= and VREF= options in front of the histogram bars.

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Displays fitted gamma density curves on the histogram. You can specify the following gamma-options:
arguments.help: GAMMA(ALPHADELTA= | ALPHAINITIAL= | MAXITER= | SIGMA= | ALPHA= | THETA= | COLOR= | CONTENTS= | FILL | L= | W= | MIDPERCENTS | NOPRINT | PERCENTS=)

arguments.name: GAMMA=
arguments.description: Specifies the second shape parameter, γ, for Johnson SB and Johnson SU distribution functions requested with the SB and SU options.

arguments.name: GRID
arguments.description: Displays a grid on the histogram.

arguments.name: GUMBEL
arguments.description: Displays fitted Gumbel density curves on the histogram. You can specify the GUMBEL option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of Gumbel curves. Use the MU= and the SIGMA= Gumbel-options to specify the location parameter μ and the scale parameter σ, respectively. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for μ and σ.

arguments.name: HANGING
arguments.description: Requests a hanging histogram,

arguments.name: HAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of an AXIS statement describing the horizontal axis.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height, in percentage screen units, of text for axis labels, tick mark labels, and legends. This option takes precedence over the HTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: HMINOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the horizontal axis. Minor tick marks are not labeled. By default, HMINOR=0.

arguments.name: HOFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the offset, in percentage screen units, at both ends of the horizontal axis.

arguments.name: HREF=
arguments.description: Draws reference lines that are perpendicular to the horizontal axis at the values that you specify.

arguments.name: HREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the HREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can have up to 16 characters.

arguments.name: HREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical position of the HREFLABELS= labels.
Along top of plot
Staggered from top to bottom of plot
Along bottom of plot
Staggered from bottom to top of plot

arguments.name: IGAUSS
arguments.description: displays fitted inverse Gaussian density curves on the histogram. You can specify the IGAUSS option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of inverse Gaussian curves. Use the MU= and the LAMBDA= iGauss-options to specify the location parameter μ and the shape parameter λ, respectively. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE uses the sample mean for μ and computes a maximum likelihood estimate for λ.

arguments.name: INFONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a software font to use for text inside the framed areas of the plot. The INFONT= option takes precedence over the FTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: INHEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height, in percentage screen units, of text used inside the framed areas of the histogram. By default, the height specified by the HEIGHT= option is used. If you do not specify the HEIGHT= option, the height specified with the HTEXT= option in the GOPTIONS statement is used.

arguments.name: INTERBAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the space between histogram bars in percentage screen units.

arguments.name: INTERTILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the distance in horizontal percentage screen units between the framed areas, called tiles, of a comparative plot. By default, INTERTILE=0.75 percentage screen units. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. You can specify INTERTILE=0 to create contiguous tiles.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Requests a table that shows the iteration history and optimizer details of the maximum likelihood parameter estimation of a Weibull distribution that is requested by the WEIBULL or WEIBULL2 option.

arguments.name: K=
arguments.description: Specifies the kernel function (normal, quadratic, or triangular) used to compute a kernel density estimate.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Normal kernel function

arguments.name: QUADRATIC
arguments.description: Quadratic kernel function

arguments.name: TRIANGULAR
arguments.description: Triangular kernel function

arguments.name: KERNEL=
arguments.description: Superimposes kernel density estimates on the histogram. You can specify the kernel-options described below:
arguments.help: KERNEL=C= | COLOR= | FILL | K= | L= | LOWER | UPPER | W=

arguments.name: L=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the L= option in parentheses after the distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of line types in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: specifies the shape parameter λ for fitted curves that are requested by the IGAUSS option. Enclose the LAMBDA= option in parentheses after the IGAUSS distribution keyword. If you do not specify a value for λ, the procedure calculates a maximum likelihood estimate.

arguments.name: LGRID=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for the grid when a grid displays on the histogram.

arguments.name: LHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for the reference lines that you request with the HREF= option. By default, LHREF=2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: LOGNORMAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted lognormal distribution function on the histogram. You can specify the following lognormal-options:
arguments.help: LOGNORMAL<(SIGMA= | THETA= | ZETA= | COLOR= | CONTENTS= | FILL | L= | MIDPERCENTS | NOPRINT | PERCENTS= | W=)>

arguments.name: LOWER=
arguments.description: Specifies lower bounds for kernel density estimates requested with the KERNEL option.

arguments.name: LSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line types for the reference lines that you request in the STATREF= option. If you specify a single line type, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if fewer line types are specified than reference lines are requested, the remaining lines are displayed with the default reference line type.

arguments.name: LVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for lines requested with the VREF= option. By default, LVREF=2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations in the Newton-Raphson approximation of the maximum likelihood estimate of α for gamma distributions requested with the GAMMA option and c for Weibull distributions requested with the WEIBULL and WEIBULL2 options. Enclose the MAXITER= option in parentheses after the GAMMA, WEIBULL, or WEIBULL2 keywords. The default value of n is 20.

arguments.name: MAXNBIN=
arguments.description: Limits the number of bins displayed in the comparative histogram.

arguments.name: MAXSIGMAS=
arguments.description: Limits the number of bins displayed in the comparative histogram to a range of value standard deviations (of the data in the key cell) above and below the mean of the data in the key cell.

arguments.name: MIDPERCENTS
arguments.description: Requests a table listing the midpoints and percentage of observations in each histogram interval.

arguments.name: MIDPOINTS=
arguments.description: Specifies how to determine the midpoints for the histogram intervals, where values determines the width of the histogram bars as the difference between consecutive midpoints.

arguments.name: values
arguments.description: The values must be listed in increasing order and must be evenly spaced. The difference between consecutive midpoints is used as the width of the histogram bars.

arguments.name: KEY
arguments.description: The procedure first determines the midpoints for the data in the key cell. The initial number of midpoints is based on the number of observations in the key cell by using the method of Terrell and Scott (1985). The midpoint list for the key cell is then extended in either direction as necessary until it spans the data in the remaining cells.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: The procedure determines the midpoints using all the observations as if there were no cells. In other words, the number of midpoints is computed from the total sample size by using the method of Terrell and Scott (1985).

arguments.name: MU=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameter, µ, for normal density curves requested with the NORMAL option.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a name for the plot, up to eight characters long, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu for a traditional graphics chart. The default value is 'UNIVAR'.

arguments.name: NCOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns per panel in a comparative plot. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. By default, NCOLS=1 if you specify only one CLASS variable, and NCOLS=2 if you specify two CLASS variables. If you specify two CLASS variables, you can use the NCOLS= option with the NROWS= option.

arguments.name: NENDPOINTS=
arguments.description: Uses histogram interval endpoints as the tick mark values for the horizontal axis and determines the number of bins.

arguments.name: NMIDPOINTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of histogram intervals.

arguments.name: NOBARS
arguments.description: Suppresses drawing of histogram bars, which is useful for viewing fitted curves only.

arguments.name: NOCURVELEGEND
arguments.description: Suppresses the legend for fitted curves. This option applies only to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: NOFRAME
arguments.description: Suppresses the frame around the subplot area.

arguments.name: NOHLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses the label for the horizontal axis. You can use this option to reduce clutter.

arguments.name: NOPLOT
arguments.description: Suppresses the creation of a plot. Use this option when you only want to tabulate summary statistics for a fitted density or create an OUTHISTOGRAM= data set.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses tables summarizing the fitted curve. Enclose the NOPRINT option in parentheses following the distribution option.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted normal density curves on the histogram. You can specify the following normal-options:
arguments.help: NORMAL<(MU= | SIGMA= | COLOR= | CONTENTS= | FILL | L= | MIDPERCENTS | W=)>

arguments.name: NOTABCONTENTS
arguments.description: Suppresses the table of contents entries for tables produced by the HISTOGRAM statement.

arguments.name: NOVLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses the label for the vertical axis. You can use this option to reduce clutter.

arguments.name: NOVTICK
arguments.description: Suppresses the tick marks and tick mark labels for the vertical axis. This option also suppresses the label for the vertical axis.

arguments.name: NROWS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows per panel in a comparative plot. This option is not available unless you use the CLASS statement. By default, NROWS=2. If you specify two CLASS variables, you can use the NCOLS= option with the NROWS= option.

arguments.name: ODSFOOTNOTE=
arguments.description: Adds a footnote to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE statement as the graph footnote.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE1
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE statement as the graph footnote.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the graph footnote. The string can contain either of the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSFOOTNOTE2=
arguments.description: Adds a secondary footnote to ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTE2
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS FOOTNOTE2 statement as the secondary graph footnote.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the secondary graph footnote. The string can contain either of the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSTITLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a title for ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: TITLE
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE statement as the graph title.

arguments.name: TITLE1
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE statement as the graph title.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all titles from the graph.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: Uses the default ODS Graphics title (a descriptive title that consists of the plot type and the analysis variable name).

arguments.name: LABELFMT
arguments.description: Uses the default ODS Graphics title with the variable label instead of the variable name.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the graph title. The string can contain the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: ODSTITLE2=
arguments.description: Specifies a secondary title for ODS Graphics output.

arguments.name: TITLE2
arguments.description: Uses the value of the SAS TITLE2 statement as the secondary graph title..

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: Uses the specified string as the secondary graph title. The string can contain the following escaped characters, which are replaced with the appropriate values from the analysis: \n is replaced by the analysis variable name, or \l is replaced by the analysis variable label (or name if the analysis variable has no label).

arguments.name: OPTBOUNDRANGE=
arguments.description: Defines the sampling range for each parameter during maximum likelihood estimation for the Johnson SU distribution. PROC UNIVARIATE computes initial estimates for each parameter by using the method of percentiles. The value determines the range of parameter values around the initial estimate that can be sampled for local optimization starting values. By default, OPTBOUNDRANGE=100.

arguments.name: OPTMAXITER=
arguments.description: Limits the number of iterations that are used by the optimizer in maximum likelihood estimation for the Johnson SU distribution. By default,OPTMAXITER=500.

arguments.name: OPTMAXSTARTS=
arguments.description: Defines the maximum number of starting points to use for local optimization in maximum likelihood estimation for the Johnson SU distribution. That is, no more than N local optimizations are used in the multi-start algorithm. By default, OPTMAXSTARTS=100.

arguments.name: OPTPRINT
arguments.description: Prints the iteration history for the Johnson SU distribution maximum likelihood estimation.

arguments.name: OPTSEED=
arguments.description: specifies a positive integer seed for generating random number sequences in Johnson SU distribution maximum likelihood estimation. You can use this option to replicate results from different runs.

arguments.name: OPTTOLERANCE=
arguments.description: specifies the tolerance for declaring optimality in maximum likelihood estimation for the Johnson SU distribution. By default, OPTTOLERANCE=1E–8.

arguments.name: OUTHISTOGRAM=
arguments.description: Creates a SAS data set that contains information about histogram intervals.

arguments.name: OUTKERNEL=
arguments.description: Creates a SAS data set that contains information about kernel density estimates.

arguments.name: OVERLAY
arguments.description: Specifies that plots associated with different levels of a CLASS variable be overlaid onto a single plot, rather than displayed as separate cells in a comparative plot.

arguments.name: PARETO
arguments.description: Displays fitted generalized Pareto density curves on the histogram. You can specify the this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of generalized Pareto curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= Pareto-option to specify Θ. By default, THETA=0. Use the SIGMA= and the ALPHA= Pareto-options to specify the scale parameter sigma and the shape parameter a. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for σ and a.

arguments.name: PERCENTS=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of percents for which quantiles calculated from the data and quantiles estimated from the fitted curve are tabulated.

arguments.name: PFILL=
arguments.description: Specifies a pattern used to fill the bars of the histograms (or the areas under a fitted curve if you also specify the FILL option) when producing traditional graphics.

arguments.name: POWER
arguments.description: Displays fitted power function density curves on the histogram. You can specify this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of power function curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= and SIGMA= power-options to specify Θ and σ. The default values are 0 and 1, respectively. Use the ALPHA= power-option to specify the and the shape parameter, a. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes a maximum likelihood estimate for a.

arguments.name: RAYLEIGH
arguments.description: Displays fitted Rayleigh density curves on the histogram. You can specify this option only once in a HISTOGRAM statement, but it can request any number of Rayleigh curves. The parameter Θ must be less than the minimum data value. Use the THETA= Rayleigh-option to specify Θ. By default, THETA=0. Use the SIGMA= Rayleigh-option to specify the scale parameter σ. By default, PROC UNIVARIATE computes maximum likelihood estimates for σ.

arguments.name: RTINCLUDE
arguments.description: Includes the right endpoint of each histogram interval in that interval.

arguments.name: SB
arguments.description: Displays fitted Johnson sB density curves on the histogram.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Is an alias for the SIGMA= option for distributions requested by the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, SB, SU, WEIBULL, and WEIBULL2 options and for the ZETA= option for distributions requested by the LOGNORMAL option.

arguments.name: SHAPE=
arguments.description: Is an alias for the ALPHA= option for distributions requested by the GAMMA option, for the SIGMA= option for distributions requested by the LOGNORMAL option, and for the C= option for distributions requested by the WEIBULL and WEIBULL2 options.

arguments.name: SIGMA=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameter, σ, for distribution functions requested by the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, NORMAL, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: STATREF=
arguments.description: draws reference lines at the values of the statistics that are requested in the space-delimited keyword-list. Keywords can be MAX, MEAN, MEDIAN, Q2, MIN, MODE, P p, Q1, Q3, factor STD. These reference lines are perpendicular to the horizontal axis in a histogram or CDF plot, and perpendicular to the vertical axis in a probability or Q-Q plot (unless the ROTATE option is specified). The STATREF= option does not apply to the PPPLOT statement.

arguments.name: STATREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines that you request in the STATREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can be up to 16 characters long.

arguments.name: STATREFSUBCHAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a substitution character (such as #) for labels that you specify in the STATREFLABELS= option. When the labels are displayed in a graph, the first occurrence of the specified character in each label is replaced with the value of the corresponding STATREF= statistic.

arguments.name: SU
arguments.description: Displays fitted Johnson SU density curves on the histogram.

arguments.name: THETA=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower threshold parameter, θ, for curves requested with the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, SB, SU, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: THRESHOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower threshold parameter, θ, for theoretical cumulative distribution functions requested with the BETA, EXPONENTIAL, GAMMA, LOGNORMAL, and WEIBULL options.

arguments.name: TURNVLABELS
arguments.description: Turns the characters in the vertical axis labels so that they display vertically. This happens by default when you use a hardware font.

arguments.name: UPPER=
arguments.description: Specifies upper bounds for kernel density estimates requested with the KERNEL option.

arguments.name: VAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of an AXIS statement describing the vertical axis. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can alternatively specify a value-list for the vertical axis.

arguments.name: VAXISLABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a label for the vertical axis. Labels can have up to 40 characters.

arguments.name: VMINOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the vertical axis. Minor tick marks are not labeled. The default is zero.

arguments.name: VOFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the offset, in percentage screen units, at the upper end of the vertical axis.

arguments.name: VREF=
arguments.description: Draws reference lines perpendicular to the vertical axis at the values specified. Also see the CVREF= and LVREF= options.

arguments.name: VREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the VREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can have up to 16 characters.

arguments.name: VREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the horizontal position of the VREFLABELS= labels.
Labels are positioned at the left of the plot.
Labels are positioned at the right of the plot.

arguments.name: VSCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies the scale of the vertical axis for a histogram.

arguments.name: COUNT
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of the number of observations per data unit.

arguments.name: PERCENT
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of percent of observations per data unit. This is the default.

arguments.name: PROPORTION
arguments.description: Scales the data in units of proportion of observations per data unit.

arguments.name: W=
arguments.description: Specifies the width in pixels of the curve or reference line associated with a distribution or kernel density estimate. Enclose the W= option in parentheses after the distribution option or the KERNEL option. In a HISTOGRAM statement, you can specify a list of widths in parentheses for multiple density curves.

arguments.name: WAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, for the axes and frame.

arguments.name: WBARLINE=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of bar outlines when producing traditional graphics.

arguments.name: WEIBULL
arguments.description: Displays a fitted Weibull density curves on the histogram. You can specify the following Weibull-options:
arguments.help: WEIBULL(C= | CDELTA= | CINITIAL= | MAXITER= | SIGMA= | THETA= | COLOR= | CONTENTS= | FILL | L= | W= | MIDPERCENTS | NOPRINT | PERCENTS=)

arguments.name: WGRID=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness for the grid when producing traditional graphics.

arguments.name: WHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the HREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all HREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: WSTATREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the STATREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all STATREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: WVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness, in pixels, of the reference lines that you request using the VREF= option. If you specify a single thickness, it is used for all VREF= lines. Otherwise, if you specify fewer thicknesses than reference lines, the remaining lines are displayed using the default thickness.

arguments.name: ZETA=
arguments.description: Specifies a value for the scale parameter, ζ, for lognormal density curves requested with the LOGNORMAL option.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: Specifies one or more variables to include in the table of extreme observations. The corresponding values of the ID variables appear beside the n largest and n smallest observations, where n is the value of NEXTROBS= option. You can also include ID variables in the output data set created by an OUTPUT statement by specifying the IDOUT option in the PROC UNIVARIATE statement.

statements.name: INSET
statements.description: An INSET statement places a box or table of summary statistics, called an inset, directly in a graph created with a CDFPLOT, HISTOGRAM, PPPLOT, PROBPLOT, or QQPLOT statement.

arguments.name: CFILL=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the background (including the header background if you do not specify the CFILLH= option). CFILL=BLANK leaves the background uncolored and prevents items from showing through the inset.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the background (including the header background if you do not specify the CFILLH= option). CFILL=BLANK leaves the background uncolored and prevents items from showing through the inset.

arguments.name: BLANK
arguments.description: Leaves the background uncolored and prevents items from showing through the inset.

arguments.name: CFILLH=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the header background for traditional graphics. The default value is the CFILL= color.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the frame for traditional graphics. The default value is the same color as the axis of the plot.

arguments.name: CHEADER=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the header text for traditional graphics. The default value is the CTEXT= color.

arguments.name: CSHADOW=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the drop shadow for traditional graphics. By default, if a CSHADOW= option is not specified, a drop shadow is not displayed.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the text for traditional graphics. The default value is the same color as the other text on the plot.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Specifies that data coordinates are to be used in positioning the inset with the POSITION= option.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Requests that PROC UNIVARIATE display customized statistics from a SAS data set in the inset table.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: Specifies the font of the text for traditional graphics. By default, if you locate the inset in the interior of the plot, then the font is SIMPLEX. If you locate the inset in the exterior of the plot, then the font is the same as the other text on the plot.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies a format for all the values in the inset.

arguments.name: HEADER=
arguments.description: Specifies the header text. The string cannot exceed 40 characters. By default, no header line appears in the inset.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of the text for traditional graphics.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: Determines the position of the inset. The position is a compass point keyword, a margin keyword, or a pair of coordinates (x,y). You can specify coordinates in axis percent units or axis data units. The default value is NW, which positions the inset in the upper left (northwest) corner of the display.

arguments.name: REFPOINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference point for an inset that PROC UNIVARIATE positions by a pair of coordinates with the POSITION= option.

arguments.name: BR
arguments.description: Bottom right

arguments.name: BL
arguments.description: Bottom left (the default)

arguments.name: TR
arguments.description: Top right

arguments.name: TL
arguments.description: Top left

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement saves statistics and BY variables in an output data set. When you use a BY statement, each observation in the OUT= data set corresponds to one of the BY groups. Otherwise, the OUT= data set contains only one observation. You can use any number of OUTPUT statements in the UNIVARIATE procedure. Each OUTPUT statement creates a new data set containing the statistics specified in that statement. You must use the VAR statement with the OUTPUT statement. The OUTPUT statement must contain a specification of the form keyword=names or the PCTLPTS= and PCTLPRE= specifications.

arguments.name: CSS=
arguments.description: Sum of squares corrected for the mean

arguments.name: CV=
arguments.description: Percent coefficient of variation

arguments.name: GINI
arguments.description: Gini's mean difference

arguments.name: KURTOSIS=
arguments.description: Measures heaviness of tails.

arguments.name: LCLM=
arguments.description: One-sided confidence limit below the mean

arguments.name: MAD
arguments.description: Median absolute difference about the median

arguments.name: MAX=
arguments.description: Maximum value

arguments.name: MEAN=
arguments.description: Arithmetic mean

arguments.name: MEDIAN=
arguments.description: Middle value

arguments.name: MIN=
arguments.description: Minimum value

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: Most frequent value

arguments.name: MSIGN
arguments.description: Sign statistic

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Number of observations that are not missing

arguments.name: NMISS=
arguments.description: Number of observations that are missing

arguments.name: NORMALTEST
arguments.description: Test statistic for normality

arguments.name: P10=
arguments.description: 10th percentile

arguments.name: P1=
arguments.description: 1st percentile

arguments.name: P25=
arguments.description: 25th percentile

arguments.name: P5=
arguments.description: 5th percentile

arguments.name: P75=
arguments.description: 75th percentile (upper quartile)

arguments.name: P90=
arguments.description: 90th percentile

arguments.name: P95=
arguments.description: 95th percentile

arguments.name: P99=
arguments.description: 99th percentile

arguments.name: PROBM
arguments.description: Probability of a greater absolute value for the sign statistic

arguments.name: PROBN
arguments.description: Probability value for the test of normality

arguments.name: PROBS
arguments.description: Probability value for the signed rank test

arguments.name: PROBT=
arguments.description: Two-tailed probability value for the Student's t statistic

arguments.name: Q1=
arguments.description: Lower quartile (25th percentile)

arguments.name: Q3=
arguments.description: Upper quartile (75th percentile)

arguments.name: QN
arguments.description: Qn, alternative to MAD

arguments.name: QRANGE=
arguments.description: Interquartile range and is calculated as Q3-Q1

arguments.name: RANGE=
arguments.description: Range calculated as the difference between maximum value and minimum value.

arguments.name: SIGNRANK
arguments.description: Signed rank statistic

arguments.name: SKEWNESS=
arguments.description: Measures the tendency of the deviations to be larger in one direction than in the other.

arguments.name: SN
arguments.description: Sn, alternative to MAD

arguments.name: STDDEV=
arguments.description: Standard deviation

arguments.name: STDERR=
arguments.description: Standard error of the mean

arguments.name: STD_GINI
arguments.description: Gini's standard deviation

arguments.name: STD_MAD
arguments.description: MAD standard deviation

arguments.name: STD_QN
arguments.description: Qn standard deviation

arguments.name: STD_QRANGE
arguments.description: Qn standard deviation

arguments.name: STD_SN
arguments.description: Sn standard deviation

arguments.name: SUM=
arguments.description: Sum

arguments.name: SUMWGT=
arguments.description: Sum of the weights

arguments.name: T=
arguments.description: Student's t statistic

arguments.name: UCLM=
arguments.description: One-sided confidence limit above the mean

arguments.name: USS=
arguments.description: Uncorrected sum of squares

arguments.name: VAR=
arguments.description: Variance

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Identifies the output data set.

arguments.name: PCTLNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more suffixes to create the names for the variables that contain the PCTLPTS= percentiles.

arguments.name: PCTLPRE=
